body: Thoughts @buengese and @olihey ? Is `+` OK in Jottacloud filenames?

No, maybe it shouldn't have failed? The file was uploaded outside of rclone, if that makes any difference..
EDIT: It fails with a folder named "Notepad++", but not with a file.

I know that Jottacloud can handle these characters. A quick test: Upload a file "notepad++.exe" to Archive in the official WebUI. Then it can be found with the API, at url `https://jfs.jottacloud.com/jfs/<Username>/Jotta/Archive/<path>/notepad%2B%2B.exe`, where the returned XML says `<file name="notepad++.exe" ...`.

In C# I have used Uri.EscapeUriString, and found that at least "+" and "#" had to be escaped manually, but I don't know the complete list.. I could have just supplied a pull request, but was a bit unsure if there were any special reasons for rclone to use the unicode variants, since I can see that also the OneDrive and at some extent Box backends also does it..

I was wrong in my initial comment. The way `ls` is implemented right now it has to fail. The characters that get replaced should be reserved character i.e. you shouldn't be able to create files or folders with that name in web ui. I just rechecked all the characters we are currently replacing with jottacloud and appears `!, &, :, %, #, ', ~` are actually ok too. 

I'm unsure if jottacloud changed there behavior there or if I made some mistake when initially testing those because I remember testing all of these extensively.
Strange. It is actually more than a year since my tests discovered that + and # had to be escaped extra, so I don't understand what was different in your tests.

Ok more testing, more strange results. I can create a folder folder names `test#` via API but not via webui. (This might be a bug in the webui) Additionally i can create a folder named `:test` on the Archive Mountpoint but not on the Sync Mountpoint. (This actually makes sense because filenames in Sync need to be Windows compatible but might be a problem for us)

Go allready url encodes `#`, `+` works if you URL encode it manually. I believe jottacloud's reserved characters need a lot more testing now.

I guess you are testing on Linux or OS X, as colon is not valid in filenames on Windows..

I have just done some testing on Windows: Generated a set of files, each with name consisting of a decimal code followed by the corresponding character for all characters within the range 0-879, which includes most relevant characters from Latin (basic, supplement, extended a and b, and IPA extensions), spacing modifiers and combining diacritical marks. I then used Jottacloud's web ui to upload the generated files, and then download them again. Then I compared the downloaded set of files with the original generated set:
- The set of generated files is 839 files, excluding files with characters not valid in Windows filenames: 0-31 (control characters), 34 (double quote), 42 (asterisk), 47 (forward slash), 58 (colon), 60 (less-than), 62 (greater-than), 63 (question mark), 92 (backslash), 124 (vertical line).
- The file with the character code 127 (DEL) are missing from Jottacloud, so it this character is not supported.
- The following characters are accepted in filenames by Jottacloud, but they are replaced with a different character:
   - 832 (Combining Grave Tone Mark) is replaced by 768 (Combining Grave Accent) when uploading to Jottacloud.
   - 833 (Combining Acute Tone Mark) is replaced by 769 (Combining Acute Accent)
   - 835 (Combining Greek Koronis) is replaced by 787 (Combining Comma Above)
   - 836 (Combining Greek Dialytika Tonos) is replaced by two characters 776 (Combining Diaeresis) and 769 (Combining Acute Accent).
- No difference if upload to Archive or Sync mountpoint.

So within the 1 byte range 0-255 all characters allowed in Windows except DEL (127) are supported by Jottacloud. Many of the more extended Unicode characters are also supported, but some of them will be replaced by similar looking characters (I did some not so systematic tests with many more Unicode characters than listed above, and saw the same).

Next thing is to find out which of the allowed characters must be percent encoded in the API requests, and which of them must be manually encoded because the default URL encoding functionality does not. I guess handling the characters in range 0-255 would be a good start..

@buengese wrote:
> Go allready url encodes #, + works if you URL encode it manually. I believe jottacloud's reserved characters need a lot more testing now.

If you comment out the replacement then you can use the debug command `rclone info jottacloud:testdir` which will try all possible characters and report stuff back.  It also creates stuff that is impossible to delete sometimes ;-)

@albertony:
Nice testing - I wouldn't worry too much about the characters >= 128 - unicode handling should deal with those (rclone has some special sauce here).

> So within the 1 byte range 0-255 all characters allowed in Windows except DEL (127) are supported by Jottacloud.

That is good to know. 

> Next thing is to find out which of the allowed characters must be percent encoded in the API requests, and which of them must be manually encoded because the default URL encoding functionality does not. I guess handling the characters in range 0-255 would be a good start..

This is covered by several RFCs so I would have hoped the standard way rclone does it would work.  It might be that we need to add `rest.URLPathEscape` in some more places.  The integration tests will flush these out.

So you basically suggest removing the special `replaceReservedChars` code and see what happens, when we just use the `URLPathEscape`?

Edit: Except I don't think [percent-encoding reserved characters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percent-encoding#Percent-encoding_reserved_characters) in filenames will work then.

All the Windows reserved characters still need to be replaced. `URLPathEscape` handles escaping fine for every characters except `+` which has to be escaped because Jottacloud is not RFC compliant. There are 2 ways of doing this either changing `URLPathEscape` or doing it inside the Jottacloud backend @ncw Which would you prefer? I wouldn't worry about DEL.

Even then I see one problem the `:` character which is reserved on Windows and not working on Sync mount point but ok on Linux so it's working on the Archive mount point. Both replacing or not replacing it could potentially lead to problems but I don't think it's worth it making a distinction between mount points.

Lastly changing the replace behavior could potentially break stuff for people who have already  created files with characters previously replaced. @ncw Is that a problem for you?

~~Wouldn't something like [this](https://github.com/albertony/rclone/commit/a45e640309fa09c0596526a23db5d5c814ec97fc) be an improvement? I tortured it a bit with my "0-879" character files, and ls and copy (up and down) seem to work for all the same characters as in my test with the web ui.~~

~~It would not solve the issue with the `:` character, and I guess there could also be other characters that are possible to upload from Linux but which are not supported on Windows. I don't know how Jottacloud handles this in official clients, I mean when a Windows user downloads files uploaded from Linux..~~

Edit:

> URLPathEscape handles escaping fine for every characters except +.

It seems you are correct. I concluded there were some more it did not handle correct, but I think I must have mixed up my test cases between the original version of the backend, with different of my own test versions with and without `URLPathEscape` and `replaceReservedChars`...

So for Windows-only, as good as all legal characters in Windows, with the exception of '+', are handled correct by just doing `URLPathEscape` (not `replaceReservedChars`).

> Lastly changing the replace behavior could potentially break stuff for people who have already created files with characters previously replaced. @ncw Is that a problem for you?

Sure, that is potentially a problem. But I think it is a greater problem that rclone cannot read existing files/folders with any of the characters that `replaceReservedChars` replaces. For example rclone can only handle items with "+" in them if they were uploaded by rclone, not if uploaded via official clients/UI. List commands abort with error when they reach my existing "Notepad++" folder, which is definitely not good.

I think it is best to remove the replacing, and to do it before the next release so that not even more files are uploaded with the current replacement logic. And would this be a breaking change? I think already uploaded files can be downloaded, but will not get the replaced characters transformed back to the original. Sure, not ideal, but probably acceptable?
